strategic_profile.executive_summary: Cornell University is a private Ivy League research university in Ithaca, New York, known for its cutting-edge research and diverse academic offerings. As New York's land-grant institution, it uniquely combines eminent scholarship with democratic ideals, offering instruction across a wide array of fields.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Cornell has a highly selective admissions process with an acceptance rate around 8%.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants need to demonstrate outstanding academic potential, strong recommendations, and compelling personal statements and writing samples.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Cornell is the most educationally diverse Ivy League institution, offering a wide range of programs across its statutory and endowed colleges.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Prospective students have extensive options for interdisciplinary studies and unique programs, including those in New York City and internationally.

analyst_takeaways.insight: The university is a world-renowned research institution with abundant undergraduate research opportunities across all academic departments, including humanities and arts.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students interested in research can get involved as early as their first year and find various programs, funding, and faculty collaborations.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Cornell boasts a vibrant student life with over 1,400 student-run organizations, diverse residential communities, and strong traditions like Slope Day and Big Red ice hockey. Despite its location in a smaller city, Ithaca offers quirky shops, restaurants, and outdoor activities, ensuring students have ample social opportunities beyond academics. Greek life is also active on campus.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: The campus in Ithaca, NY, and the surrounding Finger Lakes region provide a distinct environment. Transportation services prioritize smart and sustainable movement, offering bus services (TCAT), campus-to-campus motorcoach travel, and promoting alternatives to single-occupant vehicles. This focus supports a car-free lifestyle for many students, influencing campus accessibility and environmental initiatives.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: As a leading research university and a private land-grant institution, Cornell provides extensive research opportunities for undergraduates, spanning all academic fields. This integrated approach fosters collaboration between students and faculty, allowing for participation in individual and team projects from the first year. Strong industry ties and specialized research facilities contribute to Cornell's global recognition in areas like sustainability, climate change, cancer biology, genomics, and regenerative medicine.

current_status.test_policy_details: For Fall 2025 enrollment, Cornell University is test-optional for the College of Arts and Sciences, Cornell Engineering, the College of Human Ecology, the Cornell Jeb E. Brooks School of Public Policy, and the School of Industrial and Labor Relations. Certain colleges (College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, College of Architecture, Art and Planning, and Cornell SC Johnson College of Business) will remain score-free for one more year. Standardized testing will be required for all undergraduate colleges starting Fall 2026.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Acceptance rate and applicant numbers are estimated. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed for this cycle. Common Data Set for 2024-2025 (which would cover Class of 2029 admissions) states that waitlist is not ranked.

Acceptance rate from multiple sources. Enrolled total and yield rate from Common Data Set 2024-2025. In-state and out-of-state acceptance rates for Class of 2028 are available. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed for this cycle. Common Data Set for 2024-2025 (which would cover Class of 2028 admissions) states that waitlist is not ranked.

Acceptance rate for Class of 2027 is 7.36%. Admits total from multiple sources. Total applicants also from multiple sources. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed for this cycle. Common Data Set for 2022-2023 (which would cover Class of 2027 admissions) states that waitlist is not ranked.

Acceptance rate for Class of 2026 is 7.26% and 6.9% from another source. Using 7.26% calculated from applicants and admits from Common Data Set 2022-2023. Total applicants and admits from Common Data Set 2022-2023 and other sources. Enrolled total from Common Data Set 2022-2023. Waitlist data from Common Data Set 2022-2023.

Acceptance rate for Class of 2025 is 8.69% and 8.7% from other sources. Applicants, admits, and enrolled total from Common Data Set 2021-2022. Yield rate calculated from admitted and enrolled totals. Waitlist data from Common Data Set 2021-2022. Common Data Set 2021-2022 states that waitlist is not ranked.

gpa.notes: Admitted students typically have an average unweighted GPA of 3.9, with most having nearly straight A's in honors/AP or other rigorous courses. For enrolled first-year students who reported class rank, 85.6% were in the top tenth and 95.5% were in the top quarter of their high school graduating class.

testing.policy_note: Test optional but recommended for Fall 2025 applicants (some colleges score-free for Fall 2025); required for Fall 2026 and beyond. Approximately 45% of enrollees submitted SAT scores and 15% submitted ACT scores.

colleges.name: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong interest in life sciences, environmental sciences, applied social sciences, or agriculture and food. As a statutory college, New York State residents may benefit from in-state tuition.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Environmentally conscious, scientifically curious, and community-minded problem-solvers interested in applying knowledge to real-world challenges in food, agriculture, and the environment.

majors.name: Applied Economics and Management
majors.special_requirements: Preference is given to current first-year applicants for internal transfer. Junior transfers are rarely admitted. Qualitative factors such as work experience, volunteer activities, leadership positions, and internships are considered.
majors.notes: Highly competitive major. Internal transfer applicants must meet a minimum Cornell GPA of 3.0, with a GPA of 3.3 or higher being competitive, along with successful completion of prerequisite courses. Acceptance rate is for Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management overall, major-specific data not readily available.

majors.name: Animal Science
prerequisite_courses: BIOMG 1350 Introductory Biology: Cell & Developmental Biology
weeder_courses: AN SC 1101 Animal Science: The Science, Industry and Issues
BIOMG 1350 Introductory Biology: Cell & Developmental Biology
CHEM 3570 Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
majors.notes: Internal transfer to CALS generally requires a minimum cumulative Cornell GPA of 2.5. Acceptance rate is for College of Agriculture and Life Sciences overall, major-specific data not readily available.

majors.name: Food Science
prerequisite_courses: BIOMG 1350 Introductory Biology: Cell & Developmental Biology
weeder_courses: FOOD 1101 Science and Technology of Foods
CHEM 3570 Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
majors.notes: Internal transfer to CALS generally requires a minimum cumulative Cornell GPA of 2.5. Acceptance rate is for College of Agriculture and Life Sciences overall, major-specific data not readily available.

colleges.name: College of Architecture, Art, and Planning
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Requires a portfolio for Architecture, Art, and Landscape Architecture applicants; Architecture requires 4 years of math. Strong creative and technical skills are essential. Participation in Dragon Day tradition is a unique cultural aspect.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Visionary and creative individuals with strong artistic and design sensibilities, who are dedicated to rigorous studio work and critical spatial thinking, often participating in unique traditions like Dragon Day.

majors.name: Architecture
majors.notes: Acceptance rate is for College of Architecture, Art, & Planning overall, major-specific data not readily available. The B.Arch is a professional degree.

colleges.name: College of Arts and Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Applicants are encouraged to have an additional unit of advanced mathematics and science, and demonstrate a strong commitment to the liberal arts and sciences through a rigorous high school curriculum.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious and broad-minded students with a passion for critical thinking, diverse academic exploration, and a deep engagement with the humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences.

majors.name: Economics
weeder_courses: ECON 3110 Probability and Statistics for Economists
majors.notes: Students declare the major after completing prerequisites with specific grades (B- or better in ECON 1110/1120, C or better in MATH 1110). Acceptance rate is for College of Arts & Sciences overall, major-specific data not readily available.

majors.notes: Internal transfer to CALS Biological Sciences (similar curriculum) requires a minimum cumulative Cornell GPA of 2.75 and grades of C or better in all completed required courses for the major. Specific GPA for A&S not explicitly stated but implied to be strong. Acceptance rate is for College of Arts & Sciences overall, major-specific data not readily available.

colleges.name: Cornell SC Johnson College of Business: Charles H. Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Highly selective, emphasizes ethical and sustainable business practices. Applicants should demonstrate alignment with a 'business for a better world' ethos, strong quantitative skills, and meaningful extracurriculars. As a statutory college, NYS residents may benefit from in-state tuition.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious, analytical, and socially conscious problem-solvers who are passionate about using business and economics to create positive societal impact.

colleges.name: Cornell SC Johnson College of Business: Peter and Stephanie Nolan School of Hotel Administration
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Focuses on the hospitality industry. Applicants should demonstrate leadership experience, a strong work ethic, and appreciation for the challenges of running a business in the service industry, often through relevant work experience.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Service-oriented, entrepreneurial, and globally-minded individuals with strong interpersonal skills and a drive to innovate within the hospitality sector.

majors.name: Hotel Administration
weeder_courses: HADM 1410 Microeconomics for the Service Industry
majors.notes: Acceptance rate is for Nolan School of Hotel Administration overall, major-specific data not readily available.

colleges.name: College of Engineering
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Requires strong STEM background with rigorous coursework in math and science. Attracts students interested in a wide range of engineering disciplines and hands-on problem-solving. Known for a competitive spirit, often engaging in playful rivalry with AAP students during Dragon Day.
colleges.housing_profile: Modern dorms with maker spaces are common for engineering students in some residential areas. First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious, analytical, and innovative problem-solvers with a deep interest in applying scientific and mathematical principles to design and build solutions, often with a collaborative yet competitive drive.

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: PHYS 1110 Physics: Introduction to Experimental Physics
CS 1110 Intro to Computing: A Design and Development Perspective (Python) OR CS 1112 Intro to Computing: An Engineering and Science Perspective (MATLAB)

weeder_courses: CS 2110 Object-Oriented Programming and Data Structures
majors.notes: Highly competitive. Internal transfer to all engineering majors is possible by meeting specific affiliation requirements, which typically involve strong performance in core math, science, and introductory engineering courses. While no explicit minimum GPA to declare the major is stated beyond the general College of Engineering internal transfer guidelines, strong performance in prerequisite courses is essential. Acceptance rate is for College of Engineering overall, major-specific data not readily available.

CS 1110 Intro to Computing OR CS 1112 Intro to Computing

Internal transfer to the Engineering version requires a cumulative GPA of 2.3 or higher and at least a C- in all courses. Acceptance rate is for College of Engineering overall, major-specific data not readily available.

Internal transfer is highly selective and requires a minimum cumulative Cornell GPA of 3.0, successful completion of calculus or statistics, and introductory computing and information science core courses. Acceptance rate is for College of Engineering overall, major-specific data not readily available.

colleges.name: College of Human Ecology
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Focuses on human-centered design, health, nutrition, and public policy. Requires coursework in biology, chemistry, and/or physics, with chemistry required for certain majors or pre-health interests. As a statutory college, NYS residents may benefit from in-state tuition.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Empathetic, interdisciplinary thinkers focused on improving human lives and well-being through design, social sciences, health, and policy.

majors.name: Human Development
weeder_courses: HD 1150 Human Development: A Multidisciplinary Perspective
majors.notes: Acceptance rate is for College of Human Ecology overall, major-specific data not readily available.

majors.name: Nutritional Sciences
prerequisite_courses: NS 1150 Introduction to Nutrition: A Global Perspective
BIOMG 1350 Introductory Biology: Cell & Developmental Biology
weeder_courses: NS 1150 Introduction to Nutrition: A Global Perspective
CHEM 3570 Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
majors.notes: Internal transfer to NS in CALS requires a minimum cumulative Cornell GPA of 2.75 and B or better in NS courses (NS 1150, 1220, 2450, 2750, 3410, or 3450). Acceptance rate is for College of Human Ecology overall, major-specific data not readily available.

colleges.name: School of Industrial and Labor Relations (ILR)
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Focuses on the world of work, labor, and social justice. Strong interest in economics, sociology, psychology, and history is beneficial. As a statutory college, NYS residents may benefit from in-state tuition.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Socially conscious, analytical, and justice-oriented individuals interested in understanding and shaping the dynamics of the workplace, human resources, and public policy.

majors.name: Industrial and Labor Relations
majors.notes: Acceptance rate is for School of Industrial and Labor Relations overall, major-specific data not readily available.

colleges.name: Jeb E. Brooks School of Public Policy
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Newer school focused on public policy and healthcare policy. Requires strong quantitative and writing skills, with recommended coursework in mathematics (Calculus and/or Statistics) and science. Demonstrated engagement in extracurriculars and volunteer work reflecting public service values is important. As a statutory college, NYS residents may benefit from in-state tuition.
colleges.housing_profile: First-year students typically reside on North Campus; upper-level students have options including West Campus residential colleges, program houses, and Collegetown dorms.
colleges.student_archetype: Civically engaged, analytical, and solutions-oriented students committed to understanding and addressing complex societal challenges through policy development and implementation.

application_deadlines.notes: Binding commitment; students must withdraw other applications if admitted. Financial aid materials due by November 15.
Financial aid application materials due by February 15 for U.S. citizens and eligible non-citizens.

supplemental_requirements.details: Two supplemental essays required: one campus-wide essay on how a meaningful community has shaped the applicant (350 words), and one or more college-specific essays (prompts and word limits vary by college/school, often focusing on why the chosen major/program at Cornell).
Required for Early Decision B.Arch. applicants, submitted via Cornell SlideRoom as part of the portfolio. Responses to three prompts, each no longer than one minute.
Required for Early Decision B.Arch. applicants, submitted via Cornell SlideRoom. Assesses creative ability and commitment to the field.
Required for Regular Decision B.Arch. applicants, submitted via Cornell SlideRoom as part of the portfolio. Responses to three prompts, each no longer than one minute.
Required for Regular Decision B.Arch. applicants, submitted via Cornell SlideRoom. Assesses creative ability and commitment to the field.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Art, Landscape Architecture, Design & Environmental Analysis, Fashion Design, Fashion Design Management
supplemental_requirements.details: Required for Early Decision applicants to these programs. Specific requirements (portfolio, design challenge, index, or supplement) vary by program.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Art, Landscape Architecture, Design & Environmental Analysis, Fashion Design, Fashion Design Management
supplemental_requirements.details: Required for Regular Decision applicants to these programs. Specific requirements (portfolio, design challenge, index, or supplement) vary by program.

Optional for applicants (regardless of intended major) who believe their musical abilities will enhance their application. Not an audition for admission to a major; major application is made after enrollment. Recordings should be electronic, no longer than 10 minutes.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Looking for intellectual curiosity and drive, passion for learning, individuality, depth in pursuits, unique endeavors, and potential to contribute richly to the Cornell community and address complex global challenges through interdisciplinary approaches.

major_selection_tactics: Apply to less competitive major if not set on CS/Engineering, considering colleges like Agriculture and Life Sciences (CALS) or Industrial and Labor Relations (ILR).
Consider undeclared for Letters and Science (Arts & Sciences) if unsure of a specific major.
Research major-specific and college-specific admit rates before applying, as they vary significantly.
Ensure your application demonstrates genuine interest in the chosen major to align with admissions expectations.
Understand that your chosen major and college affect how your application is reviewed, as Cornell's admissions are decentralized by college.
college_ranking_tactics: Rank colleges based on their specific program strengths in your area of interest, rather than solely on overall university prestige.
Consider the acceptance rates of individual colleges within Cornell, as they vary significantly.
Recognize that Cornell's application review is handled by the specific college, not a central admissions office.
Prioritize colleges where your academic profile and interests best align with their specific mission and offerings.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to a competitive major (e.g., Computer Science in Engineering), consider listing a backup in a different college with potentially different admission criteria, such as Information Science in CALS or Cognitive Science in Letters and Science (Arts & Sciences). Be aware that transferring between colleges post-admission can be more challenging than changing majors within the same college.

scholarships.name: Cornell Grant
scholarships.amount: Varies based on demonstrated financial need
scholarships.deadline: February 15 (Regular Decision First-Year); March 15 (Fall Transfer); October 1 (CSS Profile available); October 1 (FAFSA available)
scholarships.benefits: Does not need to be repaid. May cover a significant portion of attendance costs.
scholarships.application_method: FAFSA and CSS Profile (for US citizens/eligible non-citizens), CSS Profile (for international students). Automatic consideration upon application for financial aid.

scholarships.name: Endowed Scholarships
scholarships.amount: Varies based on endowed fund and demonstrated financial need
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with financial aid application
scholarships.benefits: Awarded in combination with Cornell Grants; may replace a Cornell Grant, work-study, or student loan.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration for undergraduate students eligible for a Cornell Grant; no separate application required.

scholarships.name: Federal Pell Grant
scholarships.benefits: Federal grant aid that generally does not have to be repaid.
scholarships.application_method: FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid).

scholarships.name: Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG)
scholarships.benefits: Federal grant for students with exceptional financial need.
scholarships.application_method: FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid).

scholarships.name: Graduate School Fellowships and Assistantships
scholarships.amount: Full tuition coverage, health insurance, and a living allowance/stipend (e.g., $59,029 for 12 months for some programs).
scholarships.deadline: Varies by graduate program (generally with application for admission)
scholarships.benefits: Comprehensive financial support, often including full tuition, fees, health insurance, and a stipend. Opportunities for research and teaching experience.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration with application for admission to a graduate program; some may require indicating interest or a separate application.

scholarships.name: Johnson MBA Merit-Based Scholarships (Graduate)
scholarships.amount: Partial to full tuition (e.g., Park Leadership Fellowship is full tuition).
scholarships.deadline: Included in admission decision notification (no separate application for many). Deadlines align with MBA application rounds.
scholarships.benefits: Financial support for MBA studies, recognizing leadership and academic achievement.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration by an Admissions Scholarship Committee based on admission application criteria. Some specific fellowships like Park Leadership Fellowship require a separate application.

scholarships.name: External Scholarships
scholarships.benefits: Can replace loan or work components of a Cornell aid package.
scholarships.application_method: Apply directly to outside organizations. Inform Cornell's financial aid office of any awards received.

ap_policy.general_rule: Scores of 4 or 5 generally grant course credit and/or advanced placement.
exceptions: A score of 5 is often required for credit in foreign languages and chemistry.
Credit policies and applicability to degree requirements vary by individual college or school within Cornell.
AP Statistics credit is not accepted by the Brooks School of Public Policy.
ap_policy.usage: Can satisfy degree requirements, exempt students from introductory courses, and provide advanced placement.

ib_policy.general_rule: Higher Level (HL) exams with scores of 5 or above generally grant course credit.

tools: College-specific articulation agreements (e.g., with NY community colleges for CALS and Human Ecology)
transfer_articulation.restrictions: Transfer credits are typically capped at 60-66 credits. A maximum of 60 credits from community colleges is generally accepted. A minimum grade of 'C' or higher is required for transfer courses, though some departments may require a 'B' or higher for courses applied to a major. Courses must be substantially equivalent to Cornell courses in content and rigor.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework, often with a high GPA and competitive standardized test scores (though test-optional)
Demonstrated genuine passion and leadership in 1-2 focused areas, rather than a long list of unrelated extracurriculars
Authenticity and self-reflection in essays that clearly connect interests to Cornell's specific programs and values
A clear 'fit' with the specific college within Cornell to which one is applying, showcasing aligned interests and experiences
Ability to articulate how one will utilize Cornell's unique resources and contribute to its diverse community
common_activities: Research experience, particularly for science and engineering majors
Leadership roles in school clubs and organizations
Community service and civic engagement demonstrating a commitment to giving back
Participation in academic clubs related to intended major
Practical experience relevant to specific colleges (e.g., hospitality for Hotel Administration, art portfolios for AAP, agricultural experience for CALS)
essay_tips: Be specific about why Cornell and the chosen major/college, linking personal interests and experiences directly to Cornell's unique strengths and offerings
Show, don't tell: use anecdotes and specific examples to illustrate passions and motivations rather than making generic statements
Answer authentically and share a genuine story that reveals thoughts, passions, and what drives you
For the community essay, reflect on how a meaningful community has shaped your identity, values, and experiences
Clearly convey how your interests align with the college and how you would take advantage of its opportunities and curriculum
red_flags: Submitting a generic application or recycled essays that could apply to any school
Overloading the application with a multitude of unrelated extracurriculars, indicating a lack of focused passion
Failing to demonstrate a clear 'fit' or genuine interest in the specific Cornell college chosen
Ignoring the importance of standardized tests if choosing to submit them, as high scores can bolster candidacy
Underestimating Cornell's selectivity and not putting authentic effort into every part of the application
insights: Cornell values authenticity and wants to see the real you in your application.
The college within Cornell to which you apply is extremely important, as each has its own admissions office and looks for specific fit.
Cornell provides extensive resources and opportunities across a diverse academic environment, encouraging students to find their niche.
Networking and joining clubs are crucial for both academic success and building a social life at Cornell.
Successful applicants often articulate not only their academic passions but also how they plan to make an impact.
